Weâ€™re committed to learning from this case. You can read the actions we are taking and our next steps to identify learning and improve our processes, guidance and training, as well as our general approach to cases involving an allegation of discrimination.
We know that many people were concerned by the original decision we made in the case of nurse Melanie Hayes. Weâ€™re sorry that decision wasnâ€™t the right one.
The PSA then exercised its power to appeal the decision to the High Court, which ordered that nurse Melanie Hayes be struck off the register.

After we published the panelâ€™s decision, concerns were raised that the sanction might not be sufficient to protect the public. We considered the panel decision at our internal decision review group and decided to refer the case to @prof_standards (PSA).
Ms Hayes admitted all the charges, agreed with our view that her fitness to practise was impaired and accepted a six-month suspension order

We opened a fitness to practise case against nurse Melanie Hayes in 2019 after concerns were raised with us about her professional conduct. This was specifically about racially abusive comments she made.
Now #NMCCouncil will be discussing our report â€˜Learning Lessons and Improving our Handling of Discrimination Cases Reportâ€™ on the learning identified relating to the case of Melanie Hayes.

Read more about the programme here ğŸ‘‡
 https://t.co/YFDBzFEJbD

The programme is structured around a person-centred approach, ensuring that the right decision is made at the earliest opportunity in our cases and that those who are involved are heard, supported and respected

ğŸŸ¢Ensuring that we take a final decision on any case at the earliest possible stage 

ğŸŸ¢Ensuring that we make full use of the additional resources provided in our 2021-2022 budget by growing our teams and retaining team members 

ğŸŸ¢Improving the efficiency and effectiveness

Reducing the backlog of FtP cases is commitment number one in our corporate plan for 2021-2022. 

Our improvement activities are centred around

â¬‡ï¸â¬‡ï¸â¬‡ï¸

https://t.co/pH9eOn41tb
We have undertaken a comprehensive equality impact assessment to help ensure that the process is inclusive, fair and attracts a diverse pool of candidates.

The role will be open to lay applicants (people who are not and never have been, a registered nurse, midwife, or nursing associate); and the current five registrant Council members and the designate member for Scotland.
Sadly, Philip Graf stepped down due to ill-health last month. We therefore need to run an open, inclusive, competitive and robust process to appoint a new Chair.
Next up #NMCCouncil are discussing the process of appointing of a new Chair.

#NMCCouncil are now being updated on the themes identified from internal analysis of recent inquiries and investigations, and are giving feedback on the ongoing and planned work to address these themes.
Next up #NMCCouncil is invited to consider panel member reappointments, appointments to hear registration appeals and Practice Committee transfer requests.
Now #NMCCouncil are reviewing the draft corporate risk management framework.
Our consultation will give everyone a chance to have their say and shape the new standards. We will keep you updated on this! ğŸ‘

But whatâ€™s next? We had planned to launch the consultation in early Feb 21, but in view of recent pressures on health and care sectors the consultation will be delayed until March 21 at the earliest with the possibility of extending the consultation period from 12weeks to 16weeks
We are pleased to say that #NMCCouncil have approved this recommendation and agree that we can move to public consultation.

â€“ the draft Specialist Community Public Health Nursing (SCPHN) standards of proficiency; the draft community nursing Specialist Practice Qualification (SPQ) standards of proficiency; and the draft standards for post registration programmes.
The Council is recommended to agree to undertake public consultation on the following â€“

These will specify the knowledge, skills and behaviours that registered nurses and midwives require to support and care for people, communities and populations across the life course in specialist community public health nursing roles

From the outset of this project and in agreement with the PRSSG we have committed to co-produce new draft standards of proficiency for health visiting (HV), school nursing (SN) and occupational health nursing (OH) fields of SCPHN practice.
Next up #NMCCouncil are being updated on the post registration standards review, and will decide if we can proceed to public consultation. https://t.co/eOyiYK5L77
Time for a quick break. Weâ€™ll be back at 11:00 for the rest of the agenda #NMCCouncil https://t.co/MvXPHnO2Ut

You can read about these updates and more in our Executive Report 
ğŸ‘‡ https://t.co/izdK7GJUqS
As well as these updates, #NMCCouncil have also received an update on our fitness to practise caseload, the impact it is having and our plans around this

We also contacted a large sample of our register to invite them to participate in the @UKREACHStudy which is looking at if, how and why ethnicity affects Covid-19 clinical outcomes in health and care workers.

Under our #TogetherinPractice banner, coordinating and highlighting our work to promote equality, diversity and inclusion as a regulator and an employer, we published our pay gap reports - https://t.co/jAyHYwDepV

In December 2020, we responded to the Ockendon Report on the emerging findings from the independent review of maternity services at Shrewsbury and Telford Hospital NHS Trust. The second report is expected later in 2021 -https://t.co/aY4wkanGS1

The New Yearâ€™s Honours recognised a high number of nursing and midwifery professionals who we wrote to, and also published a statement celebrating the contribution of all those recognised, including Dr Gloria Rowland, our recently appointed Council Associate! https://t.co/A2Vy6pfpNP

In December we shared the final animation in our #CaringwithConfidence series all about key aspects the role of nursing or midwifery professionals, and how the Code can support you.

The consultation on our emergency rules that were introduced in response to Covid-19, which included changes to some fitness to practise and registration processes, closed on 15 January 2021.We are now analysing the results and will bring these to the #NMCCouncil in March 2021. https://t.co/mZGdJo34bn

Following careful consideration and consultation with our partners, we reintroduced the emergency standards to allow final year nursing students to opt in to support the pandemic response.

Read more about these changes ğŸ‘‡https://t.co/ow5TF5mIh1

We engaged with partners across health and social care and invited an additional two groups of nurses who trained overseas to join the temporary register. We also extended the temporary register to those who left the register between 1 March and 30 November 2020.

We recognise the fundamental importance of these issues and are committed to addressing them, itâ€™s a key part of our 2020-2025 Strategy and our new Values and Behaviours Framework.

Our paper for #NMCCouncil sets out our immediate response to the issues raised by the BLM movement following the murder of George Floyd in the USA, and the ongoing programme of work we will pursue to address concerns raised by colleagues, those on our register and the public.

The BLM movement has highlighted the issues of racial inequality and injustice experienced by black and minority ethnic people globally, including people in the UK who work for us, who use our services, and who are on our register.
#NMCCouncil are now discussing considerations for the NMC arising from the Black Lives Matter (BLM) movement.

To ensure both these groups can start making a difference as quickly as possible during this emergency, we have agreed appropriate conditions that will be placed on their temporary registration to ensure safe and supported practice.
We will then be writing to experienced former nurses and midwives who voluntarily left their professions within the last four and five years.

Next week we will write to around 2,000 nurses and midwives who have trained overseas, many are already working in health and social care and have completed the process for registration, but have not been able to sit their final examination because test centres have closed.
